question.content:
**Select all input values for which $g(x)=2$.**

[[☃ radio 1]]



[[☃ image 1]]

choices.content: There is no such input value.

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. There is a graphed function, y equals g of x, which is made up of line segments. A line segment connects negative ten, five to negative eight, seven. A line segment connects negative eight, seven to negative six, five. A line segment connects negative six, five to negative five, six. A line segment connects negative five, six to negative four, eight. A line segment connects negative four, eight to negative three, eight. A line segment connects negative three, eight to negative two, seven. A line segment connects negative two, seven to negative one, eight. A line segment connects negative one, eight to zero, seven. A line segment connects zero, seven to one, five. A line segment connects one, five to two, four. A line segment connects two, four to five, seven. A line segment connects five, seven to six, six. A line segment connects six, six to seven, four. A line segment connects seven, four to eight, four. A line segment connects eight, four to nine, three. A line segment connects nine, three to ten, four.

hints.content:
### The strategy

We should look for the points on the graph whose $y$-coordinate is the specified output $2$. [[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
Every point on the graph of a function represents a corresponding pair of input and output values.

In other words, if the point $(a,b)$ is on the graph of function $F$, then we know that $F(a)=b$.

hints.content:
### The answer

There is no point on the graph whose $y$-coordinate is $2$. In other words, there is no input value for which $g(x)=2$.

**The correct answer is *none of the above*.**



[[☃ image 1]]

A line segment connects negative ten, five to negative eight, seven. A line segment connects negative eight, seven to negative six, five. A line segment connects negative six, five to negative five, six. A line segment connects negative five, six to negative four, eight. A line segment connects negative four, eight to negative three, eight. A line segment connects negative three, eight to negative two, seven. A line segment connects negative two, seven to negative one, eight. A line segment connects negative one, eight to zero, seven. A line segment connects zero, seven to one, five. A line segment connects one, five to two, four. A line segment connects two, four to five, seven. A line segment connects five, seven to six, six. A line segment connects six, six to seven, four. A line segment connects seven, four to eight, four. A line segment connects eight, four to nine, three. A line segment connects nine, three to ten, four. There is a dashed horizontal line at y equals two, which doesn't intersect y equals g of x.
